contentrichtext.text: {{Refimprove|date=August 2008}} [[File:Constitution Hill.jpg|thumb|right|Constitution Hill from [[Wellington Arch]]]] '''Constitution Hill''' is a road in the [[City of Westminster]] in [[London]]. It connects the western end of [[The Mall (London)|The Mall]] (just in front of [[Buckingham Palace]]) with [[Hyde Park Corner]], and is bordered by [[Buckingham Palace Gardens]] and [[Green Park]]. The term "Hill" is something of a misnomer; there is barely detectable slope but most observers would regard the road as flat. An old lane on this route was enhanced in connection with the development of [[Buckingham Palace]] in the 1820s. It formed an official route from the palace to [[Hyde Park, London|Hyde Park]]. It is now closed to traffic on Sundays. The road obtained its name in the 17th century from King [[Charles II of England|Charles II]]'s habit of taking "constitutional" walks there. In Strype's Map, 1720, it is marked "Road to Kensington". In John Smith's map of 1724, it is called "Constitution Hill".<ref>Wheatley, Henry Benjamin. ''London Past and Present: Its History, Associations, and Traditions''. 1891, p. 452.</ref> It was the scene of three assassination attempts against Queen [[Victoria of the United Kingdom|Victoria]]â€”in 1840 (by [[Edward Oxford]]), 1842 (by John Francis) and 1849 (by William Hamilton). In 1850, the former [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|Prime Minister]] [[Robert Peel|Sir Robert Peel]] was thrown from his horse on Constitution Hill by the gate into Green Park; he suffered a fatal injury and died three days later. [[Wellington Arch]] at Hyde Park Corner was originally the culmination of the route, but the effect is somewhat muted now that the Arch stands at the centre of a busy traffic island. There is a recent war memorial to Commonwealth soldiers near the top of Constitution Hill, just before Hyde Park Corner; the memorial is known as the [[Memorial Gates (Constitution Hill)|Memorial Gates]]. There are other streets called 'Constitution Hill', for example in [[Birmingham]]. ==Notes== {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.ukniwm.org.uk/server/show/conMemorial.47929/fromUkniwmSearch/1 Commonwealth Gates War Memorial] *[http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/Details/Default.aspx?id=406663&mode=quick Images of Constitution Hill, London] {{coord|51.5024|-0.1464|dim:500_region:GB|display=title}} [[Category:Streets in Westminster]]
